text:
Our primary contributor to our blog has been transitioning from social media marketing to kind of full-stack content marketing. I've been sharing SEO resources, writing resources, and some general KPIs to be aware of. But I think I could be doing a better job helping her work towards tangible goals as it pertains to "what is our blog for" and "how do you know your posts are doing their job?"

Anyone have any good templates, tips, or tactics for tracking the success of a *new* blog post or piece of content? Obviously rankings don't happen overnight, so what are some ways your measure long-term SEO plays?

I would start with a brief, 1 page content strategy doc that hits on the very important question of "what is our blog for?"

If it's for the purpose of building search ranking, I would  outline the topic clusters to focus on over the next 3 months, keywords within those clusters, and set her on a path where she can say "We have 60% coverage on this topic cluster" or something like that. It's input focused. But if your blog is young, you have to start there.

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: <@UN39V47QE> I think at that level it’s better to focus on process - Are you planning a content piece targeted to a kw? Is it cannibalizing other content?
I replied out of thread - but yeah <@UJG12DM1V> s answer is a better version of mine
So, we've done that! Definitely. We have a 3-month plan w/ topics, keywords, outlined posts, and even word-count projections...
Totally agree.
I think the challenge is the "write the post, move on to the next one..." treadmill.
If you’re doing that the next big factor is inbound links
Is there a cadence you follow for checking in on that?
weekly, 30-days after publishing, 60-days... etc.?
Well usually it is a separate effort
Either outsourced or part of the job
Yup. We're a tiny team. 2 people.
So content marketing / SEO are only a fraction of our overall marketing efforts. :slightly_smiling_face:
Looking for the best way to streamline follow-up and performance check-ins without adding too much overhead, and outsourcing might be a 2020 endeavor.
Before I joined we had a SEM Rush account, but I guess they cancelled it! I might get her set up with Ahrefs, but didn't want to throw her into the deep end w/ information overload.

I'm a big fan of softer metrics this early on. I'm a marketing team of one and the blog is a very small part of my job, so what I'm looking at at the early stage is:
-- are people in the community sharing/talking about the post?
-- is it getting good comments?
-- is it getting linked in newsletters in our space?

If that stuff is happening, the organic views will follow. And those highlights are a lot more fun to share then the 200 views you have after your post has been out for a week :joy:

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: <@UJG12DM1V> Thanks, that's really helpful!

ex: we're in the data space. someone shared a recent post of ours and dj patil (former US chief data scientist) liked the twitter share. I was thrilled. Does a thing like move the needle on anything? hell no. But if we're writing stuff that catches the eye of dj patil it's relevant and good. I care about that WAY more than 100 views early on

text: I’ve been experimenting with reporting content and SEO success as paid equivalent traffic (what you would have had to pay to get that same amount of traffic) - that turns “200 views” into $5500 of traffic
that's really smart!
The main thing is it resonates with executives
It also showed us some surprising wins with posts that maybe didn’t have so much traffic but were more directed and down funnel

Random SEO question for y'all (sorry it's a bit long):

I'm at the last stage of doing a blog audit, aka doing all the redirects. We do a lot of expert webinars, and to promote the webinar, the expert was always asked to write a blog for us... but historically there was no real guidelines for that so a lot of the older posts have no SEO value and are in my list to cull.

From a "redirect to what makes the most sense" perspective, I was thinking of redirecting to the webinar landing page... but they're hosted on a subdomain, so then I was wondering if it would be better to just redirect to the list of expert webinars that is hosted on our site even if it thematically makes a bit less sense. Does anyone have any thoughts / data on redirecting to a subdomain?
Thanks Janessa! Is this worth reading if you're coming from a 'service perspective' as well?
Zero technical expertise on this subject BUT I always say go with what makes the most sense for the user. :slightly_smiling_face:

user_profile.real_name: Janessa Lantz, VP of Marketing at dbt Labs
user_profile.name: janessalantz

text: Has anyone offered free resources on Google Docs / Google Sheets? Do you have any regrets? :sweat_smile:

Clarification: The free resources are offered as templates for the construction niche (still a very paper-based industry). I do have a nice CTA with a UTM'd link on each of the resources.

Would you suggest hosting all resources on the website (Word Docs instead of Google Docs) instead?

Honestly, probably not much at stake here. Based on how you've described them, the webinar-inspired blog posts probably (1) generate little traffic and (2) have earned few links.

Redirecting to the most relevant page always makes the most sense, even if that's to a subdomain (which Google may or may not consider part of your core domain, a decision it makes algorithmically).
<@UJDPMTREY> yeah, they don't have that many links but figured it's best to cover all the bases just in case. Thanks for weighing in and kinda confirming what I was thinking!

Google will treat what it deems to be "irrelevant" redirects (e.g., redirecting a ton of pages to the homepage) as 404 errors, not 301s, so if there's _any_ link or search equity to be preserved, relevance is key.

From what I've read about your company and team, I like some of the softer metrics discussed above (i.e. PR-type "wins"), if those hold water at the top levels of the company.

I've done lots of content marketing projects for smaller sites for which the wins were traffic or links. In all honesty, I don't know that those metrics incentivized the best behavior.

The best opportunities for driving traffic are usually very high-level, far-from-the-sale terms that bring in tons of irrelevant visitors. (But look---it's "up and to the right" in Google Analytics!)

That said, links _can_ be pretty useful for a smaller site that wants to be more competitive for service/product terms (since links to blog posts boast the overall domain authority).

An interesting way to test this: Give the person three different ways to measure success (traffic, links, mentions), and see what content ideas they return with for each goal. That will give you an idea of what your measurement incentivizes, and whether that aligns with company goals.

Another thing to add here -- goals can be both stressful and motivating for junior employees. Whenever I'm setting goals with more junior team members now I emphasize when something is a learning goal vs. a performance goal (and most of the time marketers are dealing with learning goals). A learning goal is when you want to figure out _how_ something works. If we do X, what happens with Y?

So building on <@UJDPMTREY>'s point above, if you pursue X mentions for  3 months, what other metrics move along with that? In that world, you're setting a goal to see if 1. you can hit it 2. what hitting it does to other metrics

This is VERY different from a performance goal that says "if you don't hit X, you're doing a bad job". I've found that most people will assume something is a performance goal unless you tell them differently. And framing it as a learning goal puts them in a growth mindset vs. working from a place of fear or stress.

<@UPM5604VC> One of my mentors, Doug Fox, does brand positioning for a living. He hasn't written a lot on it, but he has some good resources on his site on the topic (note: one of them is his podcast ep w/ me, which was useful, but i'm not secretly trying to sell it :slightly_smiling_face: ) <https://quickbrandfox.com/sly-thoughts/>

attachments.title: Sly Thoughts
attachments.text:
One can’t be a brand champion without being quick to jump on the branding soapbox, and Brand Fox has no shortage of opinions on brand strategy:
Animalz Podcast – Brand Positioning – I sat down with Devin Bramhall from content marketing agency Animalz to discuss the importance of brand for content marketers, as well as some successful strategies they can use.
Don’t Chase Shiny Objects – Resist the urge to chase those shiny objects in marketing, or risk ending up flopping in someone’s boat. Even if sales recommended it, you’ll be the one gasping for air.
Leadership is Earned, But NEVER Marketed – Being a leader is one thing. Marketing as a leader is a very different thing. Leadership is something that is earned everyday, but never, EVER should it be marketed.
Positioned Like a Mayo Sandwich? Blame The Why – Positioning failing to connect with your audience? It could be the “Why” is to blame. Stop positioning like a mayo sandwich. Don’t forget the meat and garnish.
The 5 Commandments of Startup Branding – Thou shalt not ignore this article. Commandments tackles the 5 most common mistakes of startup branding. Avoid them and avoid the big flood to come. Sure beats building a big ark. (which investors won’t pay for)
Positioning = Adderall for Startup ADD – Know any startups suffering from ADD? Well there’s a drug for that – one with lots of benefits and few side effects. Get a Brand Positioning prescription today – 4 out of 5 brand strategists recommend it. (and the other one is busy chasing a ball)
Don’t Be A Lionel Hutz Marketer – Everybody loves Lionel Hutz, the adorable, inept lawyer on the Simpsons. In addition to defending your life, you can also get your shoes repaired, buy some real estate or have him babysit your kids, all in the same location. But is that the approach you should take with your marketing?
Branding? We Don’t Need No Stinking Branding – Much like the group of bandits getting ready to attack Rock Ridge at noon tomorrow, most entrepreneurs don’t feel the need to pay much attention to branding. Well the longer you wait to focus on brand, the harder and more costly it gets. Still the list of excuses I’ve heard over the years is long and lustrous. Lets tackle them one at a time.
Prospects Don’t Give A %$ About Your Innovation – You might be asking yourself, “Well we have a very innovative product, why shouldn’t we position around innovation?” Innovation platforms are one of the most common B2B messaging approaches, but equally one of the least effective.

text: this post kind of sums up his philosophy on brand: <https://launchx.com/blog/post?s=doug-fox-the-5-commandments-of-startup-branding>

attachments.title: Doug Fox: The 5 Commandments of Startup Branding

text: Does anybody have suggestions for content gate plugins for wordpress? Do they all suck? We have a custom built one for a report but looking to test with existing blog posts.

So we’ve done this for a few things. We are a niche industry as well (accounting/bookkeeping) and it’s great in a pinch, but I have been working to move things over to be hosted on the website. We had some people who just didn’t know how to actually download/view/copy the documents. It might depend on the industry. IMO (and coming into this role new), I wanted to make the switch to hosting on website to make the resource feel more “official” to the user.
this thread is :fire:

<@UJG12DM1V> and <@UJDPMTREY> awesome answers, thanks. I'm very clear in iterating that if we don't hit X goal it's not an indicator that *you* are doing a bad job, but _could be_ an indicator that we're missing the mark on the actual content strategy, or missing a key piece. Speaks to the learning goal and the "how" this thing works.
I think that's all really helpful, thank you! I was also very curious about tracking X KPI for Y months, and a bit of that was answered as well.

<@UJDPMTREY> Yes, we know our prospects search for and use paper versions of what our app provides. It's a risk to offer something that a prospect could keep using instead of our app, but I also like the idea of establishing trust and brand awareness.

Ah, gotcha—didn’t realize the goal was to migrate them from paper to app.

That’s an interesting challenge. The immediate thought that comes to mind is that any template that someone needs *urgently* may not work as well—they may be less willing to try/learn something new in that moment.

But maybe templates for advance planning/strategy would work?
<@UJDPMTREY> Good call on the urgency. That does change my thinking on Google doc vs. word doc.
<@UQ4P17DJS> Ease-of-use might be an issue for my audience as well. Good to know and think through!

This is an amazing exercise <@UJDPMTREY> ```An interesting way to test this: Give the person three different ways to measure success (traffic, links, mentions), and see what content ideas they return with for each goal. That will give you an idea of what your measurement incentivizes, and whether that aligns with company goals.```
I'm offering Google Doc/Sheets templates because they are something I find more interesting as a lead magnet these days...i'm just now rolling it out, so we'll see

<@UJDPMTREY> did not know this! This could help combat the ongoing argument I have against my boss who wants to redirect tens of thousands of old pages to either the homepage or category page in sake of doing each one more granularly is "too much work"
